definition.value: A <person> who receives a communication.
A <material entity> that originates a communication.
An <information content entity> transmitted from a communication source to a communication recipient.
Informational mode of delivery of radio broadcast, television, online press and printed press to a mass audience.
This is a form of mass media.

label.value: social influence intervention through mass media

definition.value: A behaviour change intervention that is an awareness of other peopleâ€™s thoughts, feelings and actions BCT delivered through a mass media mode of delivery.
Electronic mode of delivery of a newspaper or magazine.
An <increase awareness of consequences BCT> that provides information about the negative consequences of performing or not performing the behaviour.
Preferable to use the more specific child classes.
An assigned <goal> that the person has some level of commitment to.
A <drive process> in which the physiological need is acquired through experience.
A <goal> that is being pursued at any one point in time.
A <psychological need> to experience beauty.
An <affective attitude> that results from associative learning.

label.value: amount of social reinforcement for a behaviour

definition.value: A <data item> that is about the frequency and strength of social reinforcement that is experienced by the person.
<Anxiety> about the prospect of using a product of technology.
This is a fuzzy set but typically refers to use of computers and similar kinds of product.
An <environmental disposition> for a person to be valued by others.
A <communication skill> that is realised as the person expressing their views, needs or feelings whilst respecting those of others with whom they are communicating.
A <goal> that has been set by another person.
This class refers to goals that a person may or may not accept for themselves.
<Attending> where the target of attention is a goal.
<Attending> in which the target of the attention is a social norm.
This class may be used to refer to any type of norm.
A <mental disposition> that is realised by focusing one's attention on events, objects, sensory patterns or cognitive representations.
An <awareness> of a lack of resource available to another person or people relative to what they need or want.
A <goal> that is not currently being pursued.
An <individual human behaviour change> resulting from exposure to a group behavioural norm.
A <self-efficacy belief for a behaviour> that continues a behaviour pattern.
Behaviour is continued even if there are historical or current barriers to doing so.
A <disposition> that includes low capability, opportunity and motivation to enact a behaviour.

The entity "behavioural barrier" should only be applied when a behavioural barrier is underspecified or includes a combination of capability, opportunity and/or motivational disposition. If a specific capability, opportunity or motivational disposition acts as a barrier to a behaviour, then the more specific entities should be refered to.
A <stimulus> that prompts a behaviour or a behaviour pattern.
Find more specific internal stimulus classes under 'bodily behavioural cue'.
<Dissonance reduction through behaviour> where the cause of the dissonance involves cognitions about behaviour.

label.value: behavioural dissonance reduction through mental process

definition.value: <Dissonance reduction through mental process> where the cause of the dissonance involves cognitions about behaviour.
A <disposition> to have opportunity, motivation and capability or enact a behaviour.
A <mental process> that counters a behavioural impulse.
A <behavioural opportunity> that is realised by the provision of accurate information.
A <self-efficacy belief for a behaviour> following a lapse in that behaviour

label.value: belief about a behaviour meeting a need

definition.value: An <evaluative belief about the consequences of behaviour> reducing a need in some person.
A <belief> about whether there is a social rule that a behaviour must or must not occur in a given situation.
The 'social rules' referred to in the definition include laws.

label.value: belief about conformity of behaviour to personal values

definition.value: A <belief> about how far a behaviour is congruent with oneâ€™s personal values.

label.value: belief about control over valued outcomes

definition.value: A <belief> about the extent to which the person has control over outcomes that are important to them.

label.value: belief about effort required for a behaviour

definition.value: A <belief about barriers to a behaviour> in terms of level of effort required.

label.value: belief about emotional consequences of goal attainment

definition.value: A <belief about consequences of goal attainment> that focuses on the emotional response following that attainment.

label.value: belief about enablers of a behaviour

definition.value: A <belief> about factors that could facilitate or enable a behaviour.
A <belief> about the extend to which goals are achievable.
A <belief> about oneâ€™s health status.

This class covers belief about current health status. A person may have more than one such belief.

"health status" is defined as "A personal attribute that is the state of an individualâ€™s mental or physical condition."

label.value: belief about likelihood of financial consequences of a behaviour

definition.value: A <belief about likelihood of consequences of behaviour> in terms of the probability of a behaviour resulting or not resulting in a change to financial outcomes.
A <belief> about oneâ€™s own health
A <belief about severity of health condition> in terms of the outcomes of AIDS.

label.value: belief about severity of health condition

definition.value: A <belief about severity of an outcome> relating to a health condition.
A <belief about oneâ€™s social environment> that focuses on peopleâ€™s influences on each other.

label.value: belief about social influence on oneself

definition.value: A <belief about social influence> in terms of the extent to which other people influence oneâ€™s behaviour.

label.value: belief about social support for a behaviour

definition.value: A <belief about social support> for the person to enact a behaviour.
A <belief> about the degree to which a task is complex and therefore difficult to perform.

label.value: belief about the cause of a behaviour

definition.value: A <belief> about what causes or influences a behaviour.

The class 'belief about the cause of a behaviour' captures what a person believes in terms of the causes of events. A related class is 'emotional-relevance appraisal of causal agency', but this class involves an appraisal that gives raise to emotions, such as blaming yourself for an accident, giving raise to feelings of guilt.
